Q. Identify two national priorities that are part of your platform, explain your position on each and tell voters how you intend to address both. If there’s an existing bill you support to advance your position, please identify it.

1.) Inflation/greedflation/shrinkflation — while many across Montana are fighting to put food on the table and pay the unrestrained energy bills they face, property taxes have skyrocketed. Multi-national businesses in the U.S. are recording record profits, not paying their workers fair wages, and pocketing trillions via stock buy-backs all while avoiding fair taxation. We need to reduce the wage gaps at businesses because there’s no reason that a CEO makes a thousand or more times what a front-line worker makes. We need to restrict stock buy-backs at every company that gets any subsidies — that’s just transferring wealth to the wealthiest. We need to make sure that there’s fairness in the market, because right now it’s looking a lot like there’s no competition and the people are getting screwed. I would introduce clean, simple bills that address this problem.

Energy sovereignty — the grid is overwhelmed, the climate is out of control, and the costs to continue to allow a monopoly to extract exorbitant fees from captive ratepayers are unacceptable. We need to make it so that Montana — which has over 300 days of sun per year and windswept plains and valleys from Missoula to Ekalaka — has more wind and solar generation, and more independent, local micro-generation so that Montanans continue to have reliable, reasonably priced energy well into the future.

2.) Name two issues unique to the Eastern District that you will have to advance because no one else in the House will be familiar enough to do so. Explain how you’ll get the job done.

Communications — the internet is for all intents the ubiquitous tool for connecting every business to customers, and the fact that massive swaths of Montanans do not have high-speed internet is near criminal. That the FCC, USDA, NTIA and the rest of the administration have not built their application and distribution tools to work in rural and frontier communities, like those that span Montana, means we need to get in and fix how they do their jobs. In the Eastern District, not having strong internet means not having access to telehealth either. In today’s world, having high speed internet access is as essential as having heat and water in the home.

Manufacturing — with the announced closure of the sugar beet processing plant, and the recent closures of two lumber mills in Townsend and Livingston, we’ve lost nearly 500 good paying jobs in the district. We need to build up our manufacturing and work with agriculture, meat processors, and mining companies to be processing and producing value-added work to export. I’m one of the best at finding and growing bridges between businesses that benefit all participants, and I will work to expand our interdisciplinary thinking across Montana.

Q. A rare earth minerals miner in Montana recently suggested that to sustain a domestic supply of metals essential to all things tech —semiconductors, batteries, advanced military equipment — Congress would have to act. Otherwise, China, which supplies about 80% of the rare earth minerals imported by the U.S., will continue the dominate supply. Consider the traditional basket of trade options — tariffs, subsidies, government purchases, federal leasing, and environmental laws — and suggest a policy approach to this challenge.

I find it disingenuous to say that “a rare earth minerals miner” made any suggestion when it was Kendall Cotton, a Koch-funded dark money fundamentalist who would sell the Smith River to the highest bidder and not bat an eye.

That said, rare earth mineral (REM) deposits that are worth not only money being sold, but can build our economy by being refined, and put into use via manufacturing here in Montana, is absolutely a game changer, and we have to develop the smartest way to extract the REMs while also protecting our environment. And yes, while Cotton mentioned that mining processes are much improved, until they are proven it’s all just theories and guesses, and the proving grounds need to not be at the headwaters of one of our best rivers. We need to do better and protect what makes Montana special while growing our resource development.

We are a state that has created incredible technologies over the last 135 years, so with the right combination of education and investment in research, finding ways to safely mine and manage environmental impact should be an area where we lead. It’s a combination of all our historical wins.

Q. Explain how an import tariff consequential to sales of U.S. corn and soybeans to China affects the price of Montana’s top export ag commodity.

A tariff makes our products more expensive for the consumer but doesn’t add profits to the producer at all. It’s a tool used to favor home-grown produce and can be devastating to smaller producers as their product is left to rot instead of being sold. This is a problem for many reasons, but that’s why we have the Farm Bill that, currently, the House has failed to pass again and again because they refuse work for all Americans. Unlike some currently elected Congressmen, I’m uninterested in playing games that impact people’s lives. Fair taxation is fine, but playing games with taxes to create proxy wars using our economy is just reckless. We can and should be smarter.

Q. President Joe Biden has suggested “codifying Roe,” in other words creating a national right to abortion. Explain your position on this issue.

We should have done this years ago. As with all hard-won acknowledgements of rights, there will always be regressive troglodytes that want to return to the way things were because they see someone different having equal rights and perceive that somehow as a negative impact upon themselves. They are on the wrong side of history. But the fact that we don’t enshrine our rights explicitly is why we keep having to fight the same fights we’ve already won. To be clear, abortion is healthcare. Don’t like it, don’t get one, and keep your nose (and the government) out of other people’s private lives.

Q. What role would you assign yourself as a member of a slim House majority? Would you get behind policies or leaders that 90% of your party supports to advance the preferences of your caucus? Or would you use your dissent as leverage to advance positions most of your caucus didn’t support?

Anyone running for election that plans to play party politics or anti-party politics is already the wrong person to vote for. I’m not going to play games. We cannot expect to waive a magic wand to fix things. This job is about representing people and the function of representative democracy is that we do our best. Sometimes we win, sometimes we lose, but most times if we do it right, we make things incrementally better and every step in the correct direction makes us better as a whole. We do that by working together with others. It’s work that involves consideration, constant guidance, and compromise in many ways. There are very few things where a compromise won’t move the needle the way we want, and working together with people who want to work on improving all our lives is where I’ll be.

Q. Would you have certified the electors from all 50 states as a member of Congress in 2021? Explain your decision while identifying any state whose electors you would have rejected.

Yes. If anyone, especially those who currently hold office, wouldn’t, they need to resign because they were elected in the same election and if they wouldn’t certify the presidential, they shouldn’t certify or accept their own.

Editor’s note: This is one of 12 profiles featuring a candidate in Montana’s Second Congressional House District primary race. The profiles are being published daily over 12 days and in alphabetical order. Each of the candidates were asked the same questions

Democratic U.S. House candidate Steve Held offers a different take on the immigration crisis at the U.S.-Mexico border than his Republican counterparts in Montana’s eastern district.

All of the eight Republicans in the primary have made a pilgrimage to the border. Held has too. His daughter, Rikki, has been filming a documentary at the border.

“What my constituents are concerned about is the border. That's the biggest thing on people's minds. And they're worried about the border and guns and their freedoms and privacy, the Constitution. It's just basically everything. That constitution, freedom, privacy, and everything else falls below that,” Held said. “So, I went to the southern border. I was in Brownsville, Texas at the furthest most other point in Texas. I went there myself, on my own dime before work so I can't even write it off.

“I went down there because I wanted to see it. It wasn't anything like what they show on TV at all. And I talked to border agents. Of course, you know, it's like talking to a politician. You got to do it privately. They don't want you to say anything. They don't want to use your name or any of that stuff. But they do need help. The guys at the border need help. And it (ticks) me off that Rosendale refuses to sign the border bill." Republicans got 90% of what they wanted. And when I talked about it with my Republican friends, they say they got 85%, Democrats say 90%. Whatever they got.

“When you get anything in life, lean back and ride, right? We can hit the ground at any moment. You don't turn down 85 to 90% of what you want for a political agenda.”

The border bill Held is referring to is the Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan aid bill that also included $20 billion for immigration. The bill was written by Senate Republicans and Democrats in early February. The legislation was quickly abandoned by Republican lawmakers after presidential candidate Donald Trump suggested the border could wait until 2025 and the outcome of the November election.

Sen. Jim Lankford, an Oklahoma Republican who collaborated on the bill with Independent Sen. Kirsten Sinema of Arizona, Lankford told the Tulsa World that had the bill been law in the last three months of 2023, more than 800,000 would have been turned away from the United States. Within the total, was $534 million to hire thousands of new border security agents and other hires. There was $2.5 billion in the bill for “removal flights” and short-term staging facilities to repatriate aliens back to their home countries. And $3.2 billion for increased detention space.

All three of Montana’s Republican members of Congress rejected the bill.

Held is a rancher and businessman in the community of Broadus, located in the far southeast corner of the state. He’s an actor who previously worked for the Screen Actors Guild. He might be better known for daughter Rikki Held’s role as a youth plaintiff in the lawsuit Held v. Montana, a landmark case the successfully argued that Montanans constitutional right to a clean and healthful environment includes a state government response to climate change when permitting projects.

Getting a Farm Bill, one that works for Montana farmers, is a principal issue for Held. He said the farm bills too often ignore farmers and ranchers, addressing the priorities of large agribusinesses instead. He would like to see the next farm bill, which isn’t likely to advance until 2025 after the results of the November election play out.

Country of origin labeling on beef, something ranchers have fought for, but meatpackers have opposed, would be an issue Montana’s delegation should support as part of the next Farm Bill, Held said. Montanans should expect their delegation to produce laws that advance the needs of constituents.

“I talked to Daines and Tester all the time before I got into this,” Held said. “You know, I was writing to them, and I said over and over again, ‘what I want to see from the two of you is both of your names on some bills. Because that's what Montana is, to me. It's Montanans working together with a unified voice to get things done for people.’ And they did a few, you know, veteran things mostly. When they did, I thanked them.”

Q. Identify two national priorities that are part of your platform, explain your position on each and tell voters how you intend to address both. If there’s an existing bill you support to advance your position, please identify it.

1. Pass a farm bill that actually works for family farmers and ranchers, not just big agribusiness corporations. This should be a top priority for every member of Congress because our farmers and ranchers feed the world and should power it. Instead, we’ve gotten chaos while I see more and more of my friends and neighbors in agriculture struggle to make ends meet or go belly up. I would work with one of the only other real farmers in Congress, Sen. Jon Tester, and all of Montana’s farmers, ranchers, and agricultural organizations to make it the national priority it should be and it sure as heck will include mandatory Country of Origin Labeling (COOL) requirements for U.S. beef producers and consumers.

2. Pass a ban on congressional insider stock trading to clean up the corruption in the swamp. Everyone is sick of the self-serving politician
